    • Method Detail

      • readFileIntoByteData

        public static byte[][][] readFileIntoByteData(java.io.File file)
                                       throws java.io.IOException
        Reads a given bmp-file into data of it's pixels in the form data[c][x][y], where (x,y) tells the location of the pixel in the bitmap and c specifies which basic color's shade is stored in the byte (0= blue, 1 = green and 2 = red). For example data[1][0][0] tells the shade of green of the upper left corner of the image.
        Parameters:
        file - The file to be read. Must be .bmp.
        Returns:
        the color data.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • writeByteDataIntoBitmap

        public static void writeByteDataIntoBitmap(byte[][][] data,
                           java.io.File outputFile)
                                    throws java.io.IOException
        Writes raw data on the hard disk in .bmp-form. The data must be in the same form as it is read in the readFileIntoByteData-method.
        Parameters:
        data - the pixel data of the image.
        outputFile - the file into which the image will be written.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • bgrIntegerToColor

        public static byte bgrIntegerToColor(int rgbInt,
                     int color)
        Extracts shade of a basic color from the composite integer describing a pixel. The integer must be of form (0,r,g,b), that is: the first byte is meaningless, the second describes the share of red, the third the shade of green and the last one the shade of blue. To preserve the order and distance of the shades 128 is subtracted from the returning value. (Otherwise shades 127 and 128 for example would result 127 and -128 respectively.
        Parameters:
        rgbInt - The integer describing the color.
        color - The color to be extracted (BLUE = 0, Green = 1, RED = 2)
        Returns:
        The shade of the color - 128.

      • colorsToBgrInteger

        public static int colorsToBgrInteger(byte[] data)
        Combines the shades of the three basic colors into a single integer. This corresponds to the method bgrIntegerToColor, and thus values -128,...,127 of data correspond to the shades 0,...,255 of the color.
        Parameters:
        data - The shades of the three basic colors that will be combined. data[0] = blue, data[1] = green and data[2] = red.
        Returns:
        An integer in the form (0,r,g,b). That is, the first byte is empty, the second byte describes the color red, the third color green and the fourth color blue.
